BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, extensive wind slabs formed above the tree line. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. Even single winter sport participants can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on wind-loaded slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.

More gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and up to 40 cm in some localities, has fallen.
5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall in some regions.

The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes:
The high temperatures will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs and gliding snow represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. In addition an appreciable danger of wet and gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from northwesterly directions, hard wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2300 m. In particular, however, the clearly visible wind slabs are capable of being triggered in some cases still. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Skiers can release avalanches in some places, including medium-sized ones.

In particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind continuous warming. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Naturally triggered avalanches and field observations confirm a sometimes precarious avalanche situation in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition an appreciable danger of wet snow slides and avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, hard wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2300 m. In particular, however, the clearly visible wind slabs are capable of being triggered in some cases still. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

In particular in the regions exposed to the foehn wind continuous warming. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, especially on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Until Friday the wind will be strong over a wide area. As a consequence of a strong to storm force northwesterly wind, rather small wind slabs formed. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 2200 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was barely evident. The danger of ground avalanches will already exist in the early morning. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. Already in the early morning, a few, then as a consequence of warming during the day more, and in some cases even large, wet and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can still in isolated cases be released by small loads and reach medium size. Careful route selection and spacing between individuals are recommended. As the day progresses as a consequence of warming there will be a rapid increase in the danger of wet avalanches to level 3 (considerable).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of moist and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last few days. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to east to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. Caution is to be exercised at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
From starting zones where no previous releases have taken place in particular moist avalanches can in isolated cases still reach fairly large size, in particular on very steep sunny slopes below approximately 2700 m, as well as at the base of rock walls. Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. The high temperatures gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m. Field observations have indicated poor snowpack stability on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. In addition as the day progresses in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, further small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2700 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size on Saturday.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
The weather will be mild over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls above the tree line. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in all aspects. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m.
On extremely steep slopes more small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1900 m, especially at their margins. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In particular in the south and at the base of rock walls medium-sized moist loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming and solar radiation, the natural avalanche activity will increase. Moist avalanches can occur naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will become generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form on north and east facing slopes. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2400 m. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are a little more prevalent and exist in all aspects. Avalanches can in some cases reach medium size.

More gliding avalanches are possible, even quite large ones, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m, in particular in the regions with a lot of snow. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
On extremely steep slopes more small to medium-sized wet loose snow avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow will fall in particular in the north. Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall.

High altitudes and the high Alpine regions:
The northwesterly wind will transport the new snow and, in some cases, old snow as well. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers at elevated altitudes. They are in some cases prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate altitudes: Early and late morning: The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of wet snow slides and avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases even by individual winter sport participants in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain above approximately 2500 m. More recent wind slabs are to be assessed with care and prudence. As a consequence of warming during the day individual small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The strong wind has transported some snow. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2700 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition there is a danger of moist and wet avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind from northwesterly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant in particular on north to northeast to east facing aspects above approximately 2500 m. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. These are to be avoided in particular in very steep terrain. As a consequence of warming during the day more small and medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2700 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far. Along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes. On very steep sunny slopes several medium-sized to large avalanches were observed. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2700 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation individual mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In high Alpine regions there will be only a slight increase in the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: At intermediate altitudes a little snow is lying. The sometimes strong wind has transported some snow. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. The weather conditions will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming during the day individual mostly small moist and wet snow slides are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular in case of releases originating from very steep, sunny starting zones that have retained the snow thus far. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases by winter sport participants in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution. Moist snow slides are possible during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are possible, but they will be mostly small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on steep shady slopes. The old snowpack will be quite stable. Early and late morning: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind slabs and wet snow require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be mild over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes. Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Below approximately 1500 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and older wind slabs represent the main danger. Small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above the tree line. These can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects. In addition as the day progresses in particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, further small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack above the tree line. The spring-like weather conditions on Thursday gave rise to moistening of the snowpack. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of mild temperatures and the moderate to strong northwesterly wind, the snow drift accumulations will increase in size on Saturday.
